metadata.titleEn: Dataset of soil texture on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (2010)
metadata.description:
Soil data are extremely important at both global and local scales, and in the absence of reliable soil data, land degradation assessments, environmental impact studies and sustainable land management interventions are severely hampered。By Soil information data in the urgent need of the World, especially under the background of the convention on climate change, international institute for applied systems analysis (IIASA) and the UN food and agriculture organization (FAO) and the Kyoto protocol on Soil carbon measurement and the United Nations food and agriculture organization (FAO)/international global agriculture ecological assessment (GAEZ v3.0) jointly established under the sponsorship of a new generation of World Soil Database (Harmonized World Soil Database version 1.2) (HWSD V1.2).
The 2010 data set of soil texture on the qinghai-tibet plateau was culled from the world soil database.Data format :grid format, projected as WGS84.The main soil classification system used is fao-90.Unique verification identifier of core soil institution unit:
Mu_global-hwsd database soil mapping unit identifier that connects GIS layers.
MU_SOURCE1 and MU_SOURCE2- source database mapping unit identifiers；
SEQ- soil unit sequence in the composition of soil mapping unit;
Soil classification system USES fao-7 classification system or fao-90 classification system (SU_SYM74 resp.su_sym90) or fao-85 (SU_SYM85).

The main fields of the soil property sheet include:
ID(database ID)
MU_GLOBAL(soil unit identifier) (global)
SU_SYMBOL Soil mapping unit
SU_SYM74(FAO74classify );
SU_SYM85(FAO85classify);
SU_SYM90（FAO90The soil name in a soil classification system)；
SU_CODE Soil mapping unit code
SU_CODE74 Soil unit name
SU_CODE85 Soil unit name
SU_CODE90 Soil unit name
DRAINAGE(19.5);
REF_DEPTH(Soil reference depth);
AWC_CLASS(19.5);
AWC_CLASS(Soil available water content);
PHASE1: Real (The soil phase);
PHASE2: String (The soil phase);
ROOTS: String (Depth classification of obstacles to the bottom of the soil)；
SWR: String (Characteristics of soil moisture content)；
ADD_PROP: Real (A specific soil type in a soil unit that is associated with agricultural use)；
T_TEXTURE(Topsoil texture);
T_GRAVEL: Real (Percentage of aggregate volume on top)；( unit：%vol.)
T_SAND: Real (Top sand content)； ( unit：% wt.)
T_SILT: Real (surface silt content);(unit: % wt.)
T_CLAY: Real (clay content on top);(unit: % wt.)
T_USDA_TEX: Real (top-level USDA soil texture classification);(unit: name)
T_REF_BULK: Real (top soil bulk density);(unit: kg/dm3.)
T_OC: Real (top organic carbon content);(unit: % weight)
T_PH_H2O: Real (top ph) (unit: -log(H+))
T_CEC_CLAY: Real (the cationic exchange capacity of the clay layer at the top);(unit: cmol/kg)
T_CEC_SOIL: Real (cation exchange capacity of topsoil) (unit: cmol/kg)
T_BS: Real (top basic saturation);(unit: %)
T_TEB: Real (top exchange base);(unit: cmol/kg)
T_CACO3: Real (top carbonate or lime content) (unit: % weight)
T_CASO4: Real (top-level sulfate content);(unit: % weight)
T_ESP: Real (top layer exchangeable sodium salt);(unit: %)
T_ECE: Real (top-level conductivity).(unit: dS/m)
S_GRAVEL: Real (percentage of bottom gravel volume);(unit: % vol.)
S_SAND: Real (content of underlying sand);(unit: % wt.)
S_SILT: Real (substratum silt content);(unit: % wt.)
S_CLAY: Real (clay content in the bottom layer);(unit: % wt.)
S_USDA_TEX: Real (USDA underlying soil texture classification);(unit: name)
S_REF_BULK: Real (bulk density of underlying soil);(unit: kg/dm3.)
S_OC: Real (bottom organic carbon content);(unit: % weight)
S_PH_H2O: Real (base ph) (unit: -log(H+))
S_CEC_CLAY: Real (cation exchange capacity of the underlying cohesive soil);(unit: cmol/kg)
S_CEC_SOIL: Real (cation exchange capacity of underlying soil) (unit: cmol/kg)
S_BS: Real (underlying basic saturation);(unit: %)
S_TEB: Real (underlying exchangeable base);(unit: cmol/kg)
S_CACO3: Real (content of underlying carbonate or lime) (unit: % weight)
S_CASO4: Real (substrate sulfate content);(unit: % weight)
S_ESP: Real (underlying exchangeable sodium salt);(unit: %)
S_ECE: Real (underlying conductivity).(unit: dS/m)
This database is divided into two layers, in which the top layer (T) has a soil thickness of (0-30cm) and the bottom layer (S) has a soil thickness of (30-100cm).。

Refer to the instructions for other attribute values HWSD1.2_documentation.pdf，The Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD V1.2) Viewer-Chinese description andHWSD.mdb。

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics and attributes of soil texture data collected for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau in terms of both top and bottom layers?
Feature Specification.Answer: top layer (0-30 cm), bottom layer (30-100 cm), soil texture classification (FAO-90), gravel content, sand percentage, silt percentage, clay percentage, USDA texture classification, bulk density, organic carbon content, pH, cation exchange capacity, base saturation, exchangeable bases, carbonate content, sulfate content, exchangeable sodium, electrical conductivity

Comparison.Question: How do the soil classification systems used in a dataset like FAO-90 compare to other soil classification systems in terms of comprehensiveness and applicability for global soil mapping?
Comparison.Answer: The FAO-90 soil classification system used in the dataset provides a standardized approach that is comprehensive and widely applicable for global soil mapping. It allows for consistent comparison and integration of soil data from different regions. This system is particularly useful in contexts such as the Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD V1.2), as it facilitates the connection of soil mapping units with GIS layers, enhancing the reliability and utility of soil data for global assessments. Compared to other classification systems, FAO-90 may offer a more universally accepted framework, though some systems may offer more localized detail or specificity depending on the region or purpose of use.

Interpretation.Question: How can the classification of soil using systems like FAO-90 guide the development of new data collection methods for soil texture in global environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The classification of soil using systems like FAO-90 provides a standardized approach to identifying and categorizing soil characteristics, which can guide the development of new data collection methods by ensuring consistency and reliability in soil texture measurements. This can facilitate the integration of local data into global databases and support cross-regional comparisons, ultimately improving the accuracy of soil-related studies and interventions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in collecting reliable soil texture data on the Tibetan Plateau, and how do these challenges impact environmental impact studies and sustainable land management?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of reliable soil data poses significant challenges in land degradation assessment, environmental impact studies, and sustainable land management interventions. This is particularly crucial on the Tibetan Plateau, where the unique soil characteristics and extreme environmental conditions complicate data collection. The need for reliable soil data is underscored by global initiatives like the Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD), which aims to address these data gaps by providing detailed soil texture information using FAO classification systems and other soil attributes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind the creation of a soil texture dataset for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and how can it aid in overcoming challenges related to land degradation assessment and environmental impact studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives behind creating a soil texture dataset for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau involve addressing the significant challenges posed by the lack of reliable soil data, which hampers land degradation assessment, environmental impact studies, and sustainable land management interventions. By providing comprehensive soil texture data, this dataset aids in evaluating soil conditions, understanding environmental changes, and implementing effective land management strategies in response to global needs, particularly within the context of climate change conventions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in collecting and classifying soil texture data in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using the FAO soil classification systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The soil texture data collection involves using the FAO-90 classification system as the primary method. The data is collected in grid raster format with WGS84 projection. Soil classification is validated through unique identifiers such as MU_GLOBAL for global mapping units, and the classification is broken down into sequences of soil unit symbols (SU_SYMBOL, SU_SYM74, SU_SYM85, SU_SYM90) representing different FAO classification systems. Attributes like soil texture, organic carbon content, pH, and cation exchange capacity are measured for both top (0-30cm) and bottom layers (30-100cm) to provide a comprehensive understanding of soil characteristics.
